results.abstract: Images of desperate Afghans clinging to departing military planes underscored America’s blunders after 20 years in the country.
results.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Ruhullah Khapalwak

results.title: Khmer Rouge Leader Appears in Court to Appeal Genocide Conviction
results.abstract: The trial is seen as the final stage of the long-running and expensive tribunal centered on the atrocities carried out in Cambodia during the 1970s.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: The former Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan in court on Monday in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He is appealing his conviction and life sentence for genocide and other crimes.

results.abstract: “We are the only thing here,” said a cleric in Les Cayes, one of the cities worst hit by the quake. In some towns, not a church was left standing.

results.title: After 7 Years of Failing to Fix Afghanistan, Ghani Makes a Hasty Escape
results.abstract: By the time ex-president Ashraf Ghani fled the country, the hot-tempered leader was isolated and ineffective. Critics blamed him for the chaos in Kabul, saying he had betrayed his people.
results.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Nossiter

results.title: The War in Afghanistan: How It Started and How It Is Ending
results.abstract: Just as the United States was set to withdraw its military from Afghanistan after nearly 20 years of war, the Taliban took over Kabul, the country’s capital.

results.title: Deaths in custody of two brothers fuel anger over Covid enforcement in Kenya.
results.abstract: Benson and Emmanuel Ndwiga died of head and rib injuries after being detained on suspicion of breaching a curfew. The case has thrown a fresh spotlight on police brutality in the country.

multimedia.caption: People walking home along a highway on the outskirts of Nairobi, Kenya, in April. As a new wave of the coronavirus surges, the authorities have indefinitely extended a nightly curfew.

results.title: Guarding the Last Likeness of a Loathed Dictator? It’s a Thankless Job.
results.abstract: The image of Enver Hoxha, a feared tyrant, was once everywhere in Albania. His last intact statue is watched over by a partly blind, 80-year-old defender. “Nobody wants him anymore.”

multimedia.caption: A bronze statue of Enver Hoxha, Europe’s most enduring and feared communist tyrant, at a stable in the remote mountain village of Labinot Mal, in central Albania.

results.title: Malaysia’s prime minister resigns over anger about his handling of the virus.
results.abstract: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin will stay on until a successor is appointed, continuing to steer the Southeast Asian country through its worst wave of the virus yet.

results.title: Australia’s worsening outbreak raises concerns about Aboriginal communities.

results.title: In Zambia Election, Opposition Leader Storms to Decisive Win Over President
results.abstract: Voters picked Hakainde Hichilema, a businessman who had lost five previous bids for the job, to take over from Edgar Lungu, who has led the southern African nation since 2015.

multimedia.caption: Hakainde Hichilema speaking at his home in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, on Wednesday. His victory was seen as a resounding rebuke of his rival’s shepherding of an economy that was in tatters.
